awd_titl_txt: Quantum Phase Transition in Superconducting Nanowires and Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract.  
 When a material or a quantum object is cooled to ZERO temperature and is acted upon, say by pressure and magnetic field, it can transform from one state of matter to another, for example, from ferromagnetic state to non-magnetic state. Such transformations are termed quantum phase transitions (QPT); they are widespread in nature and, surprisingly, can have universal behavior in very diverse objects, such as nuclei, stars, and ordinary materials found on Earth. Still, many important characteristics of QPTs are not well-understood. The subject of this research, nanowires and thin films, undergo superconductor – normal metal QPT under the action of magnetic field or by size reduction. The team carefully studies these transformations with the goal to uncover both the universal character of QPT, but also specific microscopic processes that govern the transition in superconducting systems. Besides posing interesting fundamental questions, superconducting nanowires have immediate application in detectors used for astronomical observation and secure quantum communication. The research team collaborates with Faint Photonics Group of National Institute of Standards and Technology to improve these detectors and utilize new physical principles in detectors’ design. On a broader scale, students working on the project receive excellent training in high precision electrical instrumentation and nanofabrication. The PI has joined the University of Utah ACCESS Program that offers approximately 40 freshman female undergraduate students every year an excellent opportunity in education and research. As a part of that program, the PI serves as a research advisor to students. The PI and his students serve as volunteer judges at Utah Science Olympiads and Undergraduate Research Symposiums. 

Technical abstract
 The PI’s research addresses several outstanding problems in the field of nanoscale superconductivity and QPT. (i) The experimentally-observed suppression of critical temperature in superconducting nanowires is 100-times stronger than the prediction of existing theories. To resolve this problem, the team studies the effect of geometrical confinement on Tc (by transport measurements), on the superconducting gap (by tunneling measurement), and the superfluid density (by kinetic inductance measurements) in series of MoGe and Al nanowires with width down to 10 nm. The combined body of data is used for a theory revision. (ii) To uncover microscopic processes governing QPT in nanowires and films, the team carries out tunneling and transport measurements in the critical regime of magnetic-field-driven and size-driven transitions in MoGe and Nb films and wires. One of the goals is to understand how size-induced disorder can act as a Cooper pair breaker. (iii) A series of nanowires with the intentionally built-in strong disorder are fabricated with the expectation that they will be dominated by bosonic processes and display illusive Bose-insulator state. (iv) The team carries  wide-band, high-frequency studies of nanowires to resolve individual phase slip events and characterize their statistics. These statistics are expected to reveal interaction between phase slips and “train” effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report. Award DMR 1904221

Quantum Phase Transition in Superconducting Nanowires and Films.

Intellectual merit.

1) Impact on the principal discipline (main result):

a) The group has discovered that magnetic-field-induced Quantum Phase Transition (QPT) in superconducting film and wires occurs via the pair-breaking mechanism. In a radical departure from all previous studies, we started our analysis with subtraction of the contribution of normal electrons. The discovery has resolved several long-standing problems in the field and has invalidated the interpretation on many experimental results.  Moreover, we have discovered that the analysis can be extended beyond critical exponents and that the microscopic scale of QPT can be extracted from the data. In fact, this was crucial step in identification of the mechanism of the transition.  The analysis is illustrated  in Fig. 1.

(b) Surprisingly we found that the same pair-breaking mechanism explains the magnetic-field-driven QPT in  high-temperature superconductors. This is illustrated in Fig. 2

(c) We have also analyzed the data on one- and two- dimensional superconducting Josephson junction arrays and found that Quantum Phase Transition in these systems proceeds via so-called “phase-only” mechanism. The critical fluctuations are plasmonic excitations of the superconducting condensate, and microscopic scale is given by the screening length of Cooper pairs.    

2a) Impact on other disciplines (main result):

We have found that the method we used to discover the microscopic scale in superconducting systems is, in fact, generic and applicable to quantum phase transition in many other systems. (18 systems total so far).

Fig. 3 illustrate how the analysis works for materials composed of one-dimensional chain of spins. Then Table 1 and its captions gives the comprehensive summary of the analysis.

2b) The group also have carried out noise spectroscopy studies of perovskite solar cells and Si heterojunction solar cells, provided respectively by National Renewable Energy laboratory (Colorado) and by Competence Center for Photovoltaics, Berlin.

Broader Impacts

 1) Science.  To illustrate the broader impact of our study on science in general, let PI give a quote from the paper of Girardi-Schappo, “Brain criticality beyond avalanches: open problems and how to approach them”, (J.Phys.Complex.  2021): “… This is the reason why it is crucial to precisely determine the set of exponents that governs brain criticality. Once determined, we can be sure about what is the one theoretical model for the brain, allowing us to make better predictions and descriptions of the healthy and unhealthy brain.” This quote illustrates two points:

1)     Understanding phase transitions is important not just for physics

2)     Current studies of phase transition are overly focused on finding critical exponents

We believe that shifting focus from the exponent to other parameters, such as the microscopic scale  uncovered in our studies of QPTs, would be a fruitful approach across many science disciplines.

 

2) Training.

PI has developed a necessary infrastructure to provide an independent research project to each undergraduate student.  Students supported by the granthav have entered graduate schools of University of Utah, University of California (Irvine), Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology, University of Oklahoma, University of Oregon and joined industry (L3 Technology)

Training in PI’s has been also beneficial for graduate students and post-docs: one student supported by the grant (after short post-doc term in PI’s lab) has become Assistant Professor (Lecturer) at UU Physics and Astronomy Department. Another (female) student has assumed position as a R&D Engineer at Varex imagine corporation. A post-doc supported by the grant has got the position of Material Scientist 2 at Vaporsens/Gentex Corporation (University of Utah Research Park) 

2) Education

            In addition to his department teaching duties, PI runs a study group on quantum computing. It has been attended by several graduate and undergraduate students. The study group meets weekly and goes over the chapters and Python and Qiskit exercises given in the book of R. Hundt, Quantum computing for programmers. 
            In additoin to exploration-oriented science projects, PI started to give his undergraduates students educational projects serving as hands-on demonstrations for the general public; the project of undergraduate student, Alexander Lott, (illustrated in Fig. 4) is a good example


Last Modified: 07/31/2024
Modified by: Andrey Rogachev
